questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following statements is true?

options.b: NSAIDs act by inhibiting the phospholipases.

questions.explanation:
Cyclooxygenase-1 (COX-1) is primarily a housekeeping enzyme. NSAIDs act by inhibiting both COX-1 and COX-2. • COX-1 is constitutively expressed in most cells. It performs housekeeping functions like 
gastrointestinal cytoprotection, fluid and electrolyte balance in the kidney. • COX-2 is normally present in insignificant amounts in most of the cells. It is induced by 
cytokines, growth factors and other stimuli during inflammation. Phospholipase-A2 is the initial enzyme that acts on the membrane phospholipids to generate 
arachidonic acid. Arachidonic acid produces prostaglandins by the action of the cyclooxygenase 
enzymes (COX).

questions.question:
Question 2: A patient with a history of myocardial infarction asks you why he is being prescribed aspirin. 
You tell him it prevents the formation of clots which reduces the risk of MI. Formation of 
which of the following eicosanoids is blocked by aspirin for this purpose?
questions.explanation:
707 
Sold by @itachibot Thromboxane A2 is a pro-aggregatory eicosanoid whose formation requires the activity of COX 
enzyme. Aspirin blocks this step, thus reducing the chances of clot formation. Thromboxane A2 is an inducer of platelet aggregation and amplifies the signal of more potent 
platelet agonists, such as thrombin and ADP.

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following helps in maintaining the patency of ductus arteriosus?
questions.explanation:
Prostaglandin E1 (PGE1) maintains the patency of ductus arteriosus (PDA). This is used in term 
neonates with underlying cyanotic congenital heart disease awaiting surgical intervention as they 
have duct-dependant circulation. Indomethacin and Ibuprofen are the NSAID indicated for closing the ductus arteriosus in 
premature infants and neonates.

questions.question:
Question 4: A patient of CREST syndrome has developed pulmonary hypertension. Which of the following 
drugs will you not prescribe to treat this?
questions.explanation:
Rioprostil is a PGE1 analog and is not indicated in the treatment of pulmonary hypertension. Long term therapy with PGI2 analogs can delay or preclude the need for lung or heart-lung 
transplantation. PGI2 analogs used for the treatment of pulmonary hypertension are: • Epoprostenol (IV) • Iloprost (IV) • Treprostinil (IV or SC) PGI2 (Epoprostenol) can also be used to prevent platelet aggregation and damage during 
haemodialysis or cardiopulmonary bypass. It also improves the harvest of platelets for 
transfusion.

questions.question:
Question 5: A ‹5-year-old man has presented to the OPD with a complaint of erectile dysfunction not 
responding to oral medication. The issue is determined to be of vascular origin. Which 
prostaglandin preparation can be given as a local injection to treat this?
questions.explanation:
Alprostadil (PGE1) is given as an intracavernosal injection or urethral suppository for erectile 
dysfunction. It is considered as a second-line therapy. Its use has been largely replaced by phosphodiesterase-5 
inhibitors like sildenafil and tadalafil which are the drugs of choice.

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following statements is false about aspirin?

options.a: It is an irreversible inhibitor of the cyclooxygenase enzyme.
options.b: Its clearance is independent of plasma concentration at low dose.
options.c: Alkalinization of urine increases its rate of excretion.
options.d: Its antiplatelet effect at low dose is related to presystemic COX inhibition.

questions.explanation:
Aspirin clearance is dependent on plasma concentration at a lower dose. Aspirin shows saturation kinetics. This means that at lower plasma concentrations it has 
first-order kinetics where the rate of elimination is proportional to the plasma 708 
Sold by @itachibot concentration but at higher plasma concentrations it has zero-order kinetics where the rate of 
elimination is independent of its plasma concentration. Around 80-90% of aspirin (salicylates) are bound to plasma proteins, especially albumin. Low dose aspirin acetylates the COX enzyme of platelets in the portal circulation (pre-systemic) 
and deactivates it which is responsible for antiplatelet action. Aspirin and salicylates are acidic in nature. Alkalinization of the urine increases the rate of 
excretion of aspirin, as ionised form of aspirin increases which is not reabsorbed from the tubular 
fluid in kidney.

questions.question:
Question 7: A 12-year-old child developed fever during an epidemic of influenza. Which of the following 
drugs is contraindicated in this child?
questions.explanation:
Aspirin is contraindicated in this child due to the risk of development of Reye syndrome. Children and young adults less than 20 years of age with viral fever have a risk of developing 
Reye's syndrome on administration of aspirin or other salicylates. Features of Reye syndrome include: • Acute onset of encephalopathy • Liver dysfunction • Fatty infiltration of the liver Option A - Acetaminophen is considered the antipyretic of choice in children with viral infections. Options C and D - Oseltamivir and baloxavir are antiviral drugs used in influenza.

questions.question:
Question 8: 703 
Sold by @itachibot A 30-year-old pilot with low back pain requires a painkiller that is effective at once-daily 
dosing. You decide to prescribe the NSAID with the longest plasma half-life. Which drug will 
you choose?
questions.explanation:
Piroxicam is chosen as it has the longest plasma half-life among NSAIDs. Piroxicam is absorbed completely and undergoes enterohepatic circulation. Due to the long 
half-life, once-daily administration of the drug is sufficient for the therapeutic response.

questions.question:
Question 9: A patient with a history of gastritis complains of joint pain. You diagnose it to be a case of 
osteoarthritis and prescribe celecoxib. Which of the following statements is true regarding 
this drug?

options.b: It is more likely to cause gastric ulcers compared to ibuprofen
options.c: It is not associated with cardiotoxicity

questions.explanation:
Celecoxib is a selective COX-2 inhibitor. As COX-2 enzyme is constitutively active within the 
kidney, recommended doses of selective COX-2 inhibitors cause renal toxicities similar to those 
associated with traditional NSAIDs. Option B - It is less likely to cause gastric ulcers. Celecoxib has analgesic, antipyretic, and 
anti-inflammatory effects similar to those of non-selective NSAIDs but with better gastrointestinal 
tolerability. Option C - It inhibits COX-2-mediated prostacyclin synthesis in the vascular endothelium. As a 
result, use of celecoxib is associated with increased cardiovascular risk. 709 
Sold by @itachibot Option D - Celecoxib at usual doses does not inhibit platelet aggregation. This is because platelet 
aggregation is mediated by thromboxane produced by the COX-1. These points are also true for other selective COX-2 inhibitors.

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following drugs has the least COX-2 selectivity?
questions.explanation:
Celecoxib has the least COX-2 selectivity among the following. Some selective COX-2 inhibitors are withdrawn or have restricted use because of an increase in 
the risk of cardiovascular events like myocardial infarction, serious skin reactions (valdecoxib), 
fatal hepatic failure (lumiracoxib). Nowadays, dual inhibitors inhibiting 5-LOX and COX like licofelone and tepoxalin are also used 
for their anti-inflammatory property.

questions.question:
Question 11: Your senior asks you to administer a selective COX-2 inhibitor intravenously to a patient for 
post-op analgesia. Which of the following will you choose?
questions.explanation:
Parecoxib is chosen as it is the only injectable COX-2 selective drug among the given options. It is a water-soluble prodrug of valdecoxib. It is effective in the perioperative period when oral 
medications are not indicated.

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following is a true statement about acetaminophen?

options.a: It has significant analgesic, antiinflammatory and antipyretic action.
options.c: It does not antagonize effects of uricosuric drugs.

questions.explanation:
Acetaminophen does not antagonize effects of uricosuric agents. It may be used concomitantly 
with probenecid in the treatment of gout as it does not have any effect on uric acid levels. Option A - Acetaminophen has analgesic and antipyretic action equivalent to aspirin but lacks a 
significant anti-inflammatory effect. Option B - Acetaminophen toxicity causes centrilobular necrosis. Option D - It is a weak inhibitor of both COX-1 and COX-2 and has minimal or no effect on 
platelet activity.

questions.question:
Question 13: A 25-year-old patient of major depression presented to the ER after having consumed 20 
tablets of acetaminophen (500 mg each) 1 hour ago in a self-harm attempt. She does not have 
any symptoms at the moment. Which of the following should you administer to her?
questions.explanation:
The patient in the given clinical scenario has ingested a potentially toxic dose of acetaminophen. 
N-acetylcysteine is considered as a definitive antidote for acetaminophen poisoning to prevent 
hepatic injury. N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone imine (NAPQI) is a toxic metabolite of acetaminophen which causes 
hepatotoxicity. In adults, hepatotoxicity may occur after ingestion of a single dose of 10–15 g 
(150–250 mg/kg) of acetaminophen; doses of 20–25 g or more are potentially fatal. 710 
Sold by @itachibot In acetaminophen poisoning, due to increased NAPQI, there is utilization of glutathione (GSH). 
This in turn leads to depletion of GSH leading to oxidative cellular damage of the 
hepatocytes. N-acetylcysteine replenishes GSH stores and also conjugates with NAPQI and 
prevents oxidative damage to the cell. It also protects against extrahepatic injury due to its 
antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties. Option A: Flumazenil is an antidote for benzodiazepine toxicity. Option C: Methylene blue is used in methemoglobinemia. Option D: Symptoms may take upto 2 days to develop in a case of acetaminophen poisoning by 
which time the hepatic damage may become irreversible. Thus, early treatment is initiated in all 
suspected cases.

questions.question: Question 14: Which of the following drugs is not considered a hit and run drug?
questions.explanation:
Piroxicam is a reversible inhibitor of cyclooxygenase enzyme and cannot be considered as a hit 
and run drug. Hit and run drugs are a group of drugs whose half-life is short, but cause irreversible inhibition of 
a particular enzyme. So, the effect of the drug is present even after the drug is cleared from the 
system. Examples include: • MAO inhibitors ( e.g.: Phenelzine) • PPI (e.g.: omeprazole) • Guanethidine • Reserpine • Aspirin

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following patients should be prescribed NSAIDs for pain relief?

options.a: A hypertensive patient on chlorthalidone having osteoarthritis
options.c: Patient complaining of low back pain who is a known case of CKD

questions.explanation:
NSAIDs can be used in the treatment of primary dysmenorrhea. Prostaglandin release from 
endometrium causes cramps and other symptoms. NSAIDs inhibit the synthesis of prostaglandin 
and cause symptomatic relief. Option A: NSAIDs interfere with the antihypertensive effect of diuretics. The exact mechanism is 
not yet known. So it should be avoided in such cases. Option C: NSAIDs are generally avoided in renal diseases as inhibition of prostaglandin synthesis 
worsens renal function. Option D: NSAIDs generally lack efficacy in cases of neuropathic pain like diabetic neuropathy.

questions.question:
Question 16: A patient of chronic low back pain has presented to your OPD with deranged LFT reports. He 
tells you he has been on long term treatment with a painkiller for his condition. Which 
NSAID has he most likely been taking?
questions.explanation:
Diclofenac is the NSAID that has the highest risk of hepatotoxicity within the therapeutic dose. 711 
Sold by @itachibot Liver injury occurs in acetaminophen overdose but it is extremely rare in therapeutic dose. 
NSAIDs are not recommended in advanced hepatic and renal failure.

questions.question:
Question 17: A 30-year-old male on multiple drugs presents with a round macule on his right leg for the 
last 7 days. The patient gives a history of similar episodes in the past which resolved 
spontaneously. Which of the following drugs is the most likely cause?
questions.explanation:
This is a case of fixed drug eruption and the most likely cause is ibuprofen. Fixed drug eruptions are characterized by sharply demarcated dull red to brown lesions. They 
occur in lips, hands, legs, face, genitalia, and oral mucosa, and cause a burning sensation. The 
lesion recurs in the same locations upon re-exposure to the offending drug. Some of the drugs commonly known to cause fixed drug eruptions are Sulphonamides, NSAIDs, 
Analgesics, and Hypnotics. Diagnosis is based on history and lesion morphology. Discontinuation of the offending drug is the 
first step in management. Phenytoin and carbamazepine can lead to Stevens-›ohnson syndrome (S›S)/toxic epidermal 
necrolysis (TEN) and drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome). 712 
Sold by @itachibot Antimigraine and Antigout drugs
